column2: sure that she had roused him from his torpid condition. She wound Joe up to the starting-point
column3: just as she did her kitchen-clock
column4: and he kept upon his course as steadily as that ancient time-piece. She was just the wife for ease-loving Joe
column5: whom her brisk ways never wounded
column6: for he knew her heart was full of tenderness for him.An hour later Joe drove into the yard. Mrs. Somerby flew out with a lump of sugar for a jaded-looking horse
column7: bought by Joe to speculate upon
column8: and who ate everything he could get
column10: and never grew fat."I'll make a trotter of him in a month
column11: and sell him to some of the grandees!" Joe said
column12: but his system failed or the material was poor
column13: —old Jack slouched along as if each step was likely to be his last. But despite this
column14: Jack had become very dear to the childless couple
column15: and they were as blind as doating parents to his defects."Bless his heart!" cried Mrs. Somerby
column16: as Jack whinnied at her approach
column17: and thrust his ugly nose into her hand.
